name: Drawing and interpreting line plots involving fractions

skills.name: Drawing and interpreting line plots involving fractions (same denominator)
Drawing and interpreting line plots involving fractions with different denominators

explanations.A: You have got the correct amount of dots for each fraction but you need to put the fractions in numerical order...
explanations.B: There are four 1/4 fractions in the list so 4 dots above this fraction, there are two 1/2s so 2 dots above this fraction and there are three 3/4s so three dots above this fraction. 1/4, 1/2 and 3/4 are in numerical order so this is the correct line plot for the data set!
explanations.D: Your dots correspond to how many quarters are in each fraction, the dots need to represent how many of each fraction there are...

explanations.B: Your dots correspond to the numerator in each fraction, the dots need to represent how many of each fraction there are...
explanations.C: You have got the correct amount of dots for each fraction but you need to put the fractions in numerical order...
explanations.D: There are three 3/8 fractions in the list so 3 dots above this fraction, there are two 1/2s so 2 dots above this fraction, there are two 5/8s so two dots above this fraction and there are three 7/8s so three dots above this fraction. 3/8, 1/2, 5/8 and 7/8 are in numerical order so this is the correct line plot for the data set!

explanations.A: The mixed numbers are in numerical order and you have the correct number of dots for each: for example, there are 3 terms of 6 1/4 in the list so 3 dots go above 6 1/4 therefore A is the correct line plot!
explanations.C: You have got the correct amount of dots for each fraction but you need to put the fractions in numerical order...
explanations.D: Everything is spot on apart from the order of your fractions.. Which is smaller 6 1/2 or 6 1/4?

explanations.A: Everything is spot on apart from the order of your fractions.. Which is smaller 3 1/3 or 3 1/6?
explanations.B: You have got the correct amount of dots for each fraction but you need to put the fractions in numerical order...
explanations.D: The mixed numbers are in numerical order and you have the correct number of dots for each: for example, there are 2 terms of 2 1/2 in the list so 2 dots go above 2 1/2 therefore D is the correct line plot!

explanations.A: This is the weight of the heaviest package but the question is asking for the difference in weight between the heaviest and lightest packages...
explanations.B: This is the weight of the lightest package but the question is asking for the difference in weight between the heaviest and lightest packages...
explanations.C: The heaviest package is 3/4 and the lightest package is 1/4. To find the difference we do 3/4 - 1/4 = 2/4 = 1/2 therefore the difference between the heaviest and lightest packages is 1/2 pound
explanations.D: I think you have added the weights of the heaviest and lightest packages, but to find the difference, we need to subtract them...

explanations.A: The heaviest package is 7/8 and the lightest package is 5/8. To find the difference we do 7/8 - 5/8 = 2/8 = 1/4 therefore the difference between the heaviest and lightest packages is 1/4 pound
explanations.B: I think you have added the weights of the heaviest and lightest packages, but to find the difference, we need to subtract them...
explanations.C: This is the weight of the heaviest package but the question is asking for the difference in weight between the heaviest and lightest packages...
explanations.D: This is the weight of the lightest package but the question is asking for the difference in weight between the heaviest and lightest packages...

explanations.A: This is the difference between the heaviest and the lightest packages, the question wants the total of all the packages so you need to add the weights of the packages together...
explanations.B: To find the total weight of the packages, we need to add them: 1/4 + 1/4 + 1/4 + 2/4 + 3/4 + 3/4 = 11/4 = 2 3/4 therefore the total weight of the packages is 2 3/4 pounds.
explanations.C: This is the total of 1/4 + 1/2 + 3/4 but there are 3 packages weighing 1/4 and 2 packages weighing 3/4 not just one of each...
explanations.D: This is the total of 1/4 + 1/2 + 3/4 but there are 3 packages weighing 1/4 and 2 packages weighing 3/4 not just one of each...

explanations.A: This is the total of 2/6 + 3/6 + 4/6 but there are 3 suitcases weighing 3/6 and 2 suitcases weighing 4/6 not just one of each...
explanations.B: This is the difference between the heaviest and the lightest suitcases, the question wants the total of all the suitcases so you need to add the weights of the suitcases together...
explanations.C: To find the total weight of the suitcases, we need to add them: 2/6 + 3/6 + 3/6 + 3/6 + 4/6 + 4/6 = 19/6 = 3 1/6 therefore the total weight of the suitcases is 3 1/6 pounds.
explanations.D: This is the total of 2/6 + 3/6 + 4/6 but there are 3 suitcases weighing 3/6 and 2 suitcases weighing 4/6 not just one of each...

explanations.A: To find the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups required we need to do 3 3/8 - 2 1/8. 3 - 2 = 1 and 3/8 - 1/8 = 2/8 so the difference is 1 2/8 cups.
explanations.B: You have added but to find the difference we need to subtract...
explanations.C: This is the smallest number of cups required but the question is asking for the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups...
explanations.D: This is the largest number of cups required but the question is asking for the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups...

explanations.A: You have added but to find the difference we need to subtract...
explanations.B: To find the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups required we need to do 3 2/6 - 1 1/6. 3 - 1 = 2 and 2/6 - 1/6 = 1/6 so the difference is 2 1/6 cups.
explanations.C: This is the largest number of cups required but the question is asking for the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups...
explanations.D: This is the smallest number of cups required but the question is asking for the difference between the largest and smallest number of cups...
